results.headline: He’s the Hero of the People, and He Hates It
results.summary_short: In his directing debut, Ralph Fiennes adds modern weaponry to Shakespeare’s “Coriolanus.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Coriolanus

results.headline: The Violence That Japanese Gangsters Do: Betrayal Among the Yakuza
results.summary_short: “Outrage,” written and directed by Takeshi Kitano, describes a cycle of destruction and vengeance in a crime organization whose code of conduct is being ignored.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Outrage

results.headline: Linked Stories From the Months of the Rwanda Massacre
results.summary_short: In “Kinyarwanda,” Alrick Brown depicts a range of events and people during the months of the 1994 genocide of Tutsis in Rwanda.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kinyarwanda

results.headline: Objectification Is Also in the Eye of the Beheld
results.summary_short: Emily Browning plays Lucy, who is paid to fall into a drugged slumber in “Sleeping Beauty.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sleeping Beauty

results.headline: Dear Humans: The Planet Needs Your Help
results.summary_short: “Force of Nature: The David Suzuki Movie,” by Sturla Gunnarsson, is based on a dire speech delivered by Dr. Suzuki about the imminent destruction of the biosphere.
results.display_title: Force of Nature: The David Suzuki Movie

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Force of Nature: The David Suzuki Movie

results.headline: The Loneliness of a Brother’s Caregiver
results.summary_short: “Answers to Nothing” is Matthew Leutwyler’s film of multiple interlocking stories.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Answers to Nothing

results.headline: The Top of the World, Then Prison in Siberia
results.summary_short: The Russian Mikhail Khodorkovsky became an oligarch, but his fortunes fell when he was incarcerated. His story is the focus of a documentary by Cyril Tuschi.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Khodorkovsky

results.headline: A Zeal for Democracy in Ghana
results.summary_short: The documentary “An African Election” follows the buildup to the tumultuous 2008 presidential election in Ghana.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of An African Election

results.headline: Sparkling, Swooning and Suffering Wordlessly
results.summary_short: “The Artist” is a touching and mostly silent movie with a musical soundtrack about an aging film idol, a peppy young actress and the passing of the silent-movie era.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Artist

results.headline: Displaced, Disaffected and Desperate to Connect
results.summary_short: “A Brighter Summer Day,” the director Edward Yang’s chronicle of disaffected youth in Taiwan in 1960, seethes with the spirit of confused, ardent rebellion.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Brighter Summer Day

results.headline: Chocolate-Filled Love Story With Marshmallow on Top
results.summary_short: “Romantics Anonymous,” about two French chocolatiers who are made for each other, is like a mug of warm cocoa with marshmallow topping.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Romantics Anonymous

results.headline: The Life of a Courtesan, Viewed From the Inside
results.summary_short: “House of Pleasures,” directed by Bertrand Bonello, is not an erotic stimulant so much as a slow-moving, increasingly tragic and claustrophobic operatic pageant set almost entirely in a brothel.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of House of Pleasures

results.headline: Spreading Inner Peace, but Living With Turmoil
results.summary_short: The documentary “Crazy Wisdom” is about the life of Chogyam Trungpa, a Tibetan who was instrumental in bringing Buddhism to the West.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crazy Wisdom

results.headline: Getting the Gang Together Again
results.summary_short: In “The Muppets,” the same adorable fuzzy folks are back in theaters, as sweetly innocent and likable as ever.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Muppets

results.headline: Inventing a World, Just Like Clockwork
results.summary_short: Martin Scorsese’s 3-D film adaptation of the children’s novel “The Invention of Hugo Cabret” is also a homage to early cinema.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hugo

results.headline: Taming Unruly Desires and Invisible Monsters
results.summary_short: David Cronenberg’s “Dangerous Method” traces the shifting relationships among Carl Jung; his mentor, Sigmund Freud; and Jung’s patient, Sabina Spielrein.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Dangerous Method

results.headline: The Mysterious Mind of a Cop Who Goes Bad
results.summary_short: “Rampart,” directed by Oren Moverman and starring Woody Harrelson as a dirty Los Angeles police officer, tells a familiar story with visual punch and hustling energy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rampart

results.headline: Glamorous Sex Goddess, Longing to Be Human
results.summary_short: “My Week With Marilyn,” starring Michelle Williams as Marilyn Monroe, is based on an account by the British filmmaker Colin Clark.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Week With Marilyn

results.headline: A Son of Santa Claus Takes the Reins
results.summary_short: “Arthur Christmas” is an animated 3-D film for children with plenty of jokes for grown-ups and the voices of James McAvoy, Bill Nighy, Hugh Laurie and Jim Broadbent.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Arthur Christmas

results.headline: Twentysomething in Need of a Life Coach
results.summary_short: Joshua Leonard wrote, directed and stars in “The Lie,” in which he wonders if it is possible to rewrite lives and remake choices.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lie
